moves.1. d4: Thus begins my FIRST EVER team match! My team, the Knights Who Say Ni!, are playing against Team Checkmate.
moves.2... dxc4 3. e4: 3.Nf3 is the more flexible and quieter move; 3.e4 tends to be sharper.
moves.3... Nf6 4. e5: The good thing about 3.e4: if Black develops a piece, White is often able to push his central pawns with tempo.
moves.4... Nd5 5. Bxc4 e6 6. Nc3 Bb4 7. Bd2 Nc: Rapid development for both sides ensues; however I am not convinced that Black can shrug off the disadvantage that my powerful central pawns give him.
moves.8. Nf3 Nxc3 9. Bxc3 Bxc3+ 10. bxc3: Feel free. A series of exchanges gives me my c-pawn again, and bolsters my central pawns.
moves.10... O-O 11. O-O a6 12. Bd3: The reason for this move? In GM Yasser Seirawan's "Winning Chess Combinations" I had just discovered a chapter on the brilliant "Classical Bishop Sacrifice" which you are about to see. This stylish attacking motif captured my imagination, and I resolved to use this attack as soon as possible. This is about to be my first attempt at using it.
moves.12... b5 13. h4: The Classical Bishop Sacrifice attack runs Bxh7 Kxh7 Ng5 . 13.h4 prevents ...Qxg5. h4 also comes in to the attack after ...Kg6.
moves.14... Kxh7: As Seirawan so nicely puts it, it's a case of "damned if you do, damned if you don't". On the one hand, Black will be left a pawn down after 14.Kh8, and White retains a good attacking possibility...on the other, White's crushing attack starts after Kxh7.
moves.15... Kg8 16. Qh5: Three! Isn't it amazing how quickly the attacking pieces leap into position with this attack! Suddenly, checkmate is forced - this is why ...Kg8 is considered inferior to ...Kg6. But then, Black is in big trouble anyway.
moves.16... Re8: Escaping the checkmate in 1, but this allows a picturesque checkmate in 5.
moves.17. Qxf7+ Kh8 18. Qh5+ Kg8 19. Qh7+ Kf8: A very neat and stylish win. Remind me to use this attack more often :-).

gameName: A good start to Team matches!
